prompts: Who are key leaders (field grade officers and senior NCOâ€™s) in charge of U.S. military units combating the ebola epidemic in Africa, what are the protocols for personnel safety, and what is their mission? Units from all four services were deployed to West Africa, some 3000 personnel in all, in support of U.S. and international aid workers. The military was not directly involved in treating ebola patients. Their mission was to provide support services such as facilities construction, logistics, telecommunications, road building, etc. so that the medical aid workers could function more effectively. Additionally, the research addressed safety protocols for the U.S. forces, including mandatory quarantines upon return to their home bases. Non relevant information encompasses non-U.S. military units and civilian aid workers and U.S. military units that did not deploy to Africa.

prompts: Identify the conspiracies circulating about Ebola. Any information on conspiracy theories about Ebola is relevant. Degree of relevance was determined by the specificity of the information. Information clearly related to a hoax is not relevant. There probably is more data available on this topic.

prompts: Find mentions of attacks on people, vehicles or facilities in Africa that provide education or medical aid regarding ebola. A general statement concerning attacks is relevant. The attack must be physical, not just a threat or angry words. Identification or description of who or what was attacked is relevant. Descriptions of the attackers and motives for the attacks are relevant. Attacks on clinics, burial teams, medical personnel, and educational teams are relevant. Robbery and theft of medical supplies or blood samples is relevant. People raiding and looting a health center is relevant, but people storming a center to get treatment is NOT relevant. Attacks on security personnel or police are NOT relevant. Trying to break out of quarantine is NOT relevant. Precautions against or fear of possible attacks are NOT relevant. Remembrance of a person killed is NOT relevant unless the circumstance of the attack is described. Attacks by animal rights activists in connection with the fate of a dog belonging to an ebola victim is NOT relevant. Mere hindering or disruption of work is not an attack, and therefore NOT relevant.
reconstructed_prompt: You are interested in how many children are out of school globally and whether this number has increased over time. You may wish to compare these numbers to the pre-COVID statistics in order to better grasp the impact of the pandemic on education levels. Some resources for finding this information are provided here.
original_prompt_triplets:
1. ("get_info", "event", "attacks on people, vehicles or facilities providing education or medical aid regarding ebola in Africa")
2. ("learn", "event", "description of attackers and motives for attacks on clinics, burial teams, medical personnel, and educational teams")
3. ("get_info", "event", "robbery and theft of medical supplies or blood samples related to ebola")
4. ("get_info", "event", "raiding and looting of health centers providing ebola aid")
reconstructed_prompt_triplets:
[
  ("learn", "education", "number of children out of school globally"),
  ("analyze", "education", "increase in out of school children over time"),
  ("compare", "education", "out of school children pre-COVID statistics")
]

prompts: Who is Pauline Cafferkey? Biographical information about Pauline Cafferkey, the British nurse who contracted Ebola while volunteering in West Africa, is pertinent. Of interest is who she knows, where she lives, where she works, what her profession is, and who her family is. Mention of her tangentially in articles about other Ebola cases is not relevant. A comedian's jokes about her are not relevant. A caption identifying her from ""a Cafferkey family photo"" is not relevant. Relevancy was judged based on the specificity of the information. In the Contacts sub-topic, relevancy also was based on the likelihood that the individual knew Cafferkey directly. In all sub-topics,documents that did not mention Cafferkey by name were judged as marginally relevant or relevant.
reconstructed_prompt: You may be interested to know about the outbreak of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) caused by the virus SARS-CoV-2. This is a very important disease due to its high contagiousness and global spread causing deaths in every continent. We can find the answer for all your queries on this disease at the website of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), which is a comprehensive resource on the epidemiology, clinical features, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of the disease. If you want to know more about the source and origin of the virus, it was first identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019 and has since spread to other countries and continents.
original_prompt_triplets:
1. ("learn", "biography", "Pauline Cafferkey")
2. ("get_info", "contacts", "Pauline Cafferkey's acquaintances")
3. ("get_info", "location", "Pauline Cafferkey's residence")
4. ("get_info", "employment", "Pauline Cafferkey's workplace")
5. ("get_info", "profession", "Pauline Cafferkey's profession")
6. ("get_info", "family", "Pauline Cafferkey's family")
reconstructed_prompt_triplets:
[
  ("learn", "disease", "coronavirus disease (COVID-19)"),
  ("get_info", "virus", "SARS-CoV-2"),
  ("explore", "resource", "U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)"),
  ("learn", "epidemiology", "coronavirus disease (COVID-19)"),
  ("learn", "clinical features", "coronavirus disease (COVID-19)"),
  ("learn", "diagnosis", "coronavirus disease (COVID-19)"),
  ("learn", "treatment", "coronavirus disease (COVID-19)"),
  ("learn", "prevention", "coronavirus disease (COVID-19)"),
  ("learn", "origin", "SARS-CoV-2"),
  ("learn", "location", "Wuhan, China"),
  ("learn", "date", "December 2019")
]

prompts: How was Ebola medical waste handled? The Ebola virus was very contagious, and this fairly large outbreak created a lot of medical waste. How was all this medical waste handled? What were the dangers of this medical waste? What were the costs involved in handling the waste and disposing of it? How was this medical waste contained? And how was all this medical waste disposed of, what methods were used in various parts of the world, the USA, Africa, Europe?
reconstructed_prompt: Your organization has contracted your firm to complete an assessment of the medical waste management sector in the United States and its current status with respect to international laws and regulations in this area, especially as they relate to healthcare facility sanitation, disposal, incineration, and recycling. Your deliverables are a written assessment of the subject and a set of policy and management recommendations for your client.
original_prompt_triplets:
[
  ("learn", "medical_waste_handling", "Ebola"),
  ("analyze", "medical_waste_handling", "dangers"),
  ("analyze", "medical_waste_handling", "costs"),
  ("explore", "medical_waste_handling", "containment methods"),
  ("explore", "medical_waste_handling", "disposal methods"),
  ("compare", "medical_waste_handling", "USA"),
  ("compare", "medical_waste_handling", "Africa"),
  ("compare", "medical_waste_handling", "Europe")
]
reconstructed_prompt_triplets:
[
  ("analyze", "medical waste management", "United States"),
  ("learn", "international laws and regulations", "healthcare facility sanitation"),
  ("learn", "international laws and regulations", "disposal"),
  ("learn", "international laws and regulations", "incineration"),
  ("learn", "international laws and regulations", "recycling"),

  ("plan", "management recommendations", "medical waste management sector")
]
